source.c8c6c7a0:
# Clustering the salary group into desired class (4 categories)


# remove unwanted string character of the salary column
col_select_2021[salary_text]=col_select_2021[salary_text].map(lambda x: x.lstrip('$>'))
col_select_2021[salary_text] = col_select_2021[salary_text].replace(',','', regex=True)

# get unique value of salary range and its new class
new_unique = col_select_2021[salary_text].value_counts(normalize = True, dropna=False)
dic_unique= dict(new_unique)
keys= list(dic_unique.keys())
keys.sort(key=lambda x: [int(y) for y in x.split('-')])
dict_salary_class = {key: idx for idx, key in enumerate(keys)}
col_select_2021["salary category"] = col_select_2021[salary_text].apply(lambda x: dict_salary_class[x])


# condense  the class into 4 classes
# select the distribution(0-25K, 25K-100K, 100K-500K, >500K)
condense_cond=[
               (col_select_2021["salary category"] >= 0) & (col_select_2021["salary category"] < 10),
               (col_select_2021["salary category"] >= 10) & (col_select_2021["salary category"] < 17),
               (col_select_2021["salary category"] >= 17) & (col_select_2021["salary category"] < 24),
               (col_select_2021["salary category"] >= 24) & (col_select_2021["salary category"] <= 25),
               (col_select_2021["salary category"] > 25) & (col_select_2021["salary category"] < 0)
]

condense_value=[1,2,3,4,0]
col_select_2021["condense salary category"] = np.select(condense_cond,condense_value)

source.b3bd0b65:
def sta_sum_para_to_salary(data:pd.DataFrame, sal_cat:list, col_sum_para:list,
                          col_name_sal_cat:str)->pd.DataFrame:
    '''
    This fuction creates dataframe with list of statistical properties
    as its value.
    data = dataframe of each country which has been procesed
    salary_cat = salary category
    col_sum_para = list of columns name of the summary of the selected paramters
    output = data frame of statiscal properties of a country
    '''
    df = pd.DataFrame(columns = col_sum_para[1:])
    
    for sal_class in sal_cat:
        for sum_para in col_sum_para:
            if sum_para != "sum basic" and sal_class !=0 : # skip the basic columns and salary category of 0
                select=data.loc[data[col_name_sal_cat]==sal_class]
                if select[sum_para].tolist() != [] : 
                    mean = float('{:.{prec}f}'.format(select[sum_para].mean(), prec=1))
                    std = float('{:.{prec}f}'.format(select[sum_para].std(), prec=1))
                    med = float('{:.{prec}f}'.format(select[sum_para].median(), prec=1))  
                    mode = select[sum_para].value_counts().idxmax()
                    max_ = float('{:.{prec}f}'.format(select[sum_para].max(), prec=1))
                    min_ = float('{:.{prec}f}'.format(select[sum_para].min(), prec=1))
                    #rint(type(mode))
                    statistical_prop = [mean, std, med, mode, max_, min_]
                    df.at[sal_class, sum_para] = statistical_prop
                else:
                    df.at[sal_class, sum_para] = []
                    print(f"There is no data for {sum_para} in salary category {sal_class}")
    return df #np_country

        columns = df_country.columns
        try:
            list_sal_group = df_country.loc[i,df_country.columns[0]:df_country.columns[-1]]

We have conducted a small research about how understant the salary/compensation behaviour based on Data Science and Machine Learning Survey 2021.

according to the research, I can conclude that as a beginner we have to be aware and more efficient determining our career path and learning path. It shows that the lower salary category respondents master various tools excessively. It could be caused by many reasons. In my point of view, it caused by the vague of career plan toward future, lack of knowledge in this field (as a business), and too many options are available. As a result, we can easily be disrupted or even go to nowhere.

As an advice that I can draw from this small research is we have, at least, a strong key activities. Then from the activities we can purposely grow our expertise. We can see that even some respondents in salary category 4 focus only in one key activities. It allows them to deliver higher quality of work. Then it also confirms that QUALITY > QUANTITY.

The figure below show the plotted statistical properties of each parameter over four different salary categories. The generated plot basically can tell many things. However, I would like to cover the main idea related to our thesis/question.

In the US, if we see the pattern of the plot, you will find the huge gap on the maximum property line (green) to other statistical properties. Let's inspect the salary class 1 and 4, both have almost similar pattern. However if we go to salary category 2, the maximum summation is not more than 10 (excluding the learning path). Whereas respondents in the salary category 1 at some point reach 15 or even 20. It means that people in the salary category 1 are just mastering too many skills which are actually not really neccesary in the one step higher salary category. We can also say that there is a lower conversion rate of the respondent in the salary category 1.

Furthermore, we can see that other statistical properties are mostly in the magnitude of 2-4 even for the highest compensation. Therefore, according to the pattern, I would like to give advice for beginners (including me) to prevent ourself trying mastering many types of tools in Data Science and Machine learning. The good number of each parameter we can take might be between to 1 to 3 according to the US case.

To conduct this small research, I use the 2021 survey of Kaggle ML and Data Science. The approach is we will characterize the skillset based on salary group and country. The salary is categorized into four: 1. 0 – 25K $\rightarrow$ Category 1 2. 25K – 100K $\rightarrow$ Category 2 3. 100K – 500K $\rightarrow$ Category 3 4. $>$500K $\rightarrow$ Category

While the countries are grouped according to development status, developed and developing country since each country has different regulation in minimum salary. There six countries are selected. The three developed countries are the US, Japan, and Russia. The three developing countries are India, Brazil, and China. Besides its development status, another consideration to choose those selected above is the number of respondents. I prioritize the country which has greater number of respondents. However, there is one exceptional for Indonesia. Since I came from Indonesia, Myself is eager to know as well how my country is 😊.

With regard to characterization parameter, I try to cover all of the data science stages which are provided by the survey questions. As a result, I categorize the characteristics as below:
1. basic
The basic group contains the basic information of each respondent like following: a. Salary b. Country 2. Activities
This group uses the question “Select any activities that make up an important part of your role at work: (Select all that apply) – Selected Choice …”.
3. General
This groups means the possible common things that should be had/used by a data scientist. It is divided into three:
a. Programme language,
b. Hardware / machine,
c. Library / tools
4. Machine Learning (ML) Machine learning / deep learning is another big topic. so I group it into a section. This comprises three subgroups:
a. Framework and Algorithm, b. AutoML tools, c. Platform. 5. Big Data It contains the column related to big data products (relational database, data warehouse, data leaks, etc) 6. Source
The source of data can vary such as images and sound hence this group contains two questions. a. Computer Vision b. Natural Language Processing 7. Learning Path
The learning path contains the respondents plan to master certain topics in data science. It can be divided like below:
a. General
   i. Hardware / Machine
   ii. Tools
b. Machine learning
   i. Tools,
   ii. Platform
c. Big data
   i. big data products (relational database, data warehouse, data leaks, etc)

The detail of used question can be seen in the Implementation. In total there are 28 question used in this notebook.

Then, let’s go to our research.

Hi folks,
Motivation
This is my first experience participating in data science challenge. As a beginner, I am feeling stumbling with so many languages, platforms, tools, etc out there. I don’t know where to start. How many languages I should learn? Do I have to master all programming languages, frameworks, tools, and hardware? how the ideal number of languages, tools, hardware should be mastered? How long should I spend time? The most important thing is with the current knowledge and skills, how much can I charge for my service? Or what is the minimum skillset needed to be able get employed with minimum salary? What is the ideal path to increase my rate? And so on.

Do you also feel the same? Please continue scrolling down this notebook.

Purpose
On this notebook I am trying to explore the data scientist characteristics according to its salary. So, then we are, as a beginner, able to understand how to start, determine our growth path, and the most important thing is we are able to determine optimally the return of investment of our skills.

Wondering and hypothesis
Therefore, for this small research my question is “should we master everything to get more salary?”

My hypothesis is “we don’t have to master all to get more salary. Instead, we need to find the optimal skillsets on each class of salary”.
